banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: A brief tour of the last 4 billion years (dinosaurs not included)
videoData.socialTitle: A brief tour of the last 4 billion years (dinosaurs not included)

nodes.whoTheyAre: TED Senior Fellow Lauren Sallan is a paleobiologist using a wide variety of data and methods to reveal how biodiversity changes at scales beyond human observation (macroevolution).
nodes.whyListen:
Lauren Sallan uses the vast record of living and fossil marine ecosystems as a global, "deep time" database. She combines cutting-edge analytics with experimental results and natural observations to reveal why some species persist and diversify while others die off, and how life responds to environmental challenges big and small. She has used this multidisciplinary approach to discover the largest, "sixth" mass extinction of vertebrates, reveal the environmental origins of our earliest ancestors and show how new fish predators can shift prey ecology at global scales.

Sallan is the founder and head of the Marine Macroevolution Unit at the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST), Japan, where she leads an international team of multidisciplinary scientists. She was previously the Martin Meyerson Assistant Professor in Interdisciplinary Studies at the University of Pennsylvania, and became a TED Fellow in 2017 and a TED Senior Fellow in 2019. Her research has been published in outlets such as Science, Nature, PNAS and Current Biology, as well featured by The New York Times, the BBC, Forbes, the New Scientist, the Discovery Channel and others.

videoData.description: In this hilarious, whirlwind tour of the last four billion years of evolution, paleontologist and TED Fellow Lauren Sallan introduces us to some of the wildly diverse animals that roamed the prehistoric planet (from sharks with wings to galloping crocodiles and long-necked rhinos) and shows why paleontology is about way more than dinosaurs.
videoData.socialDescription: In this hilarious, whirlwind tour of the last four billion years of evolution, paleontologist and TED Fellow Lauren Sallan introduces us to some of the wildly diverse animals that roamed the prehistoric planet (from sharks with wings to galloping crocodiles and long-necked rhinos) and shows why paleontology is about way more than dinosaurs.

cues.text: Paleontology,
a science geared towards small children,
focused on digging up dinosaurs
while sporting a "Jurassic Park" costume.
Skulls are popped out of the ground
and put on display for public gawking.

The relevance of this, beyond clickbait,
coloring books and monster movies
is unknown.
No ...
Wait.
That's not paleontology at all.

Paleontology is nothing less
than the study of past life.
All past life.
From ancestors to alien forms.

It involves fundamental questions
like "Who are we?"
And "How did we get here?" --

using the broadest possible
definition of "we":
life itself.
Dinosaurs, a category of birds,
are just a small percentage of that.
(Laughter)
Yet they get the most media attention.

[The incredible diversity of ancient life,
Dinosaurs, Paleontology]

It's a very accurate meme;
I didn't even make this one.
This is just the truth.

Anyway, most of us paleontologists
consider dinosaurs to be a gateway drug.

There is so much cooler stuff
in the fossil record,
and we know so much about it.
Let's go on a brief, dinosaur-free tour
of the last four billion years.
(Laughter)
First up, genetic material.

Viruses, basically,
started producing proteins
and wrecking their environment.
The Earth was infected with life.

Some of these new bacteria
learned how to eat sunshine,
producing oxygen,
pulling in carbon from the air

and destroying the iron food
of other microbes
by turning it into rust.
This went on for billions of years.
Some bacteria consumed other bacteria,

gaining their power
to turn oxygen into energy,

becoming the precursors
of animals and plants.

But as a result,
there were climate shocks,
from hot to cold and back again,

which ended up turning the Earth
into a snowball covered with glaciers.

The technical term for this time period
is "Snowball Earth."
(Laughter)

Seven hundred, eight hundred
million years ago.
Anyway, microbes banded together,
creating multicellular life.
Six hundred million years ago,

geometric colonies appeared,
sucking microbes from the water.

These were soon replaced
by the ancestors of modern animals.
The Cambrian explosion.
Lobster relatives ate other animals,
capturing them using their grasping arms.

Armored wriggling clam worms
crawled across the seafloor and into it,
creating new ecosystems.

Our tadpole-like ancestors
flitted along ancient coastlines,

while their eel-like relatives
with gnashing throat teeth

swam above the ice-cream cone corals
of the first reefs,
dodging school-bus-sized krakens
and hungry sea scorpions.
Plant fungus came onto land.

But then the glaciers returned,
killing pretty much everything.
But mass extinctions open opportunities.
Jawless fishes invaded the ocean,

sporting points, prongs,
and finally, fins.

Spiders, scorpions, snails
and worms came onto land.

Somewhere around China,
a fish developed jaws,
and its descendants drove jawless fishes,
sea scorpions and branching plankton
to extinction.
Some of these fishes,
which had arm bones in their fins,
sprouted fingers,
seven or eight per flipper.
On land, plants became trees,
growing massive

or spreading their spores
only once before dying.
But then the glaciers came back again,
and it was mass extinction number two.

It was the age of weird fishes
and plated sea lilies.
Sharks with wings.
Sharks with buzz saw jaws.
Sharks with fins covered in tiny teeth.
Sharks with crushing tooth plates.

Bony fishes that looked like
modern angelfish and eels
for the first time.
Wetlands developed,

sporting ten-foot-long millipedes
and giant dragon flies.

These spread across the supercontinent
of Pangaea and died,
creating coal,
leading to a 100-million-year Ice Age.

Finally, vertebrates made it onto land
on a permanent basis,
leading to alligator-like amphibians
and saber-toothed protomammals.

But then, volcanoes erupted
all over Siberia,
everything almost died
and it was mass extinction number three.
(Laughter)
The day life nearly died.

A single, lonely tusked mammal
survived and thrived,

but it was soon replaced
by galloping crocodiles.
In the ocean, marine reptiles,

giant rafts made of the living
relatives of sea urchins

and armored squids, ammonoids,
of every kind and form.
But then, Pangaea started to split apart,
forming a sea of lava

that would one day become
the Atlantic Ocean,
spewing toxic gas into the atmosphere
and mass extinction number four.
(Laughter)

Yeah, there's actually
a lot more than these five,
these are the big ones.
(Laughter)

So, finally, there were
whale-sized fishes,
and modern fishes mobbed corals,

made gigantic by using
their captured algae to eat sunshine.

Crabs, stingrays and other fishes
with crushing teeth appeared,
smashing shells

and leading to an arms race
between predators and prey.

There was an explosion
of marine biodiversity.
Mammals climbed trees, flew

and did a lot of other things
that are seemingly sort of modern.

They were feeding on the first flowers
pollinated by the first bees.

There were ecological revolutions
on land and at sea,
leading to the modern world.
Except that an asteroid hit Mexico,

and then that triggered volcanoes
on the other side of the world in India,
and everything almost died again.
(Laughter)

But -- there's always a but,
because we're still here --
mammals arose from the ashes,

became small under extreme heat
and then ever larger.

There were palm trees
and snakes in the Arctic.

Predatory deer dogs frolicked
along ancient rivers,

while their relatives
returned to the ocean
to become the first otter-like whales.
Not hyenas and other sort of carnivores

were chased off by giant
long-necked rhinos.

Everything at this point
seems kind of familiar
but not really.
In Antarctica, an ice age started,

forming the first permanent polar ice cap
in two hundred million years.
This dried out the rest of the world,

but it allowed the rise of grasses,
of rodents, of cats.
Somewhere in Africa,

an ape started walking
across the new savannah.

Oh, and there were giant
saber-toothed salmon,
I just have to mention that.
(Laughter)
So, we know all of this happened
and so much more.
How?
Why?
Paleontology is a thriving science

at the intersection of multiple
other fields and technologies.

There is no bigger data
than the fossil record,
and we mine every bit of it.
We use CAT scans,
we use isotopes,
we use genomes,
we use robots,
we use mathematical simulations
and all kinds of analytics.

We maximize all of it
so that we can understand the past
and how evolution works.

It also lets us make
predictions for the future.

What will happen after the next
mass extinction?
What weird things will show up?
Will mammals get smaller again?
Will there even be mammals?
In sum,
we have learned a lot about dinosaurs.
But there's so much left to learn

from the other 99.9 percent of things
that have ever lived.
And that's paleontology.
Thank you.
(Applause and cheers)

footnotes.annotation:
> "Paleontology is nothing less than the study of past life. All past life. From ancestors to alien forms."

Paleontology is the study of past life as understood by the fossil record. For more, see [here](https://www.nationalgeographic.org/encyclopedia/paleontology/) and [here](https://ucmp.berkeley.edu/paleo/paleowhat.html).

> "Let's go on a brief, dinosaur-free tour of the last four billion years. First up, genetic material. Viruses, basically,
started producing proteins and wrecking their environment."

Some researchers have found chemical evidence suggesting that life may date back to four billion years ago. For more, see [here](https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/12/life-may-have-originated-earth-4-billion-years-ago-study-controversial-fossils-suggests) and [here](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2015/10/scientists-may-have-found-earliest-evidence-life-earth&source=gmail&ust=1582128169056000&usg=AFQjCNHiAl7nKVWJgpHg1fxFetDlKP_Iiw).

There is an ongoing scientific debate about what structures provided the basis of the first forms of life. For a review on the different hypotheses, see [here](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmicb.2019.00523/full).

> "But as a result, there were climate shocks, from hot to cold and back again, which ended up turning the Earth into a snowball covered with glaciers. The technical term for this time period is 'Snowball Earth.' Seven hundred, eight hundred million years ago."

This section refers to the start of the Cryogenian and Sturtian glaciation periods, which are estimated to have occurred around 700 million years ago. For more, see [here](http://francismacdonald.fas.harvard.edu/files/fmacdonald/files/cox_etal_epsl_2016.pdf).

> "Six hundred million years ago, geometric colonies appeared, sucking microbes from the water."

For more on suspension-feeding forms within the Ediacaran biota, see [here](https://advances.sciencemag.org/content/1/10/e1500800.full).

> "Armored wriggling clam worms crawled across the seafloor and into it, creating new ecosystems."

For more on the origins of early armored mollusks, see [here](https://ucmp.berkeley.edu/taxa/inverts/mollusca/polyplacophora.php) and [here](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-16304-6&source=gmail&ust=1582128169056000&usg=AFQjCNHC4X7jkzHvG2WrKbsQLGwlUSrcjQ).

> "Our tadpole-like ancestors flitted along ancient coastlines, while their eel-like relatives with gnashing throat teeth swam above the ice-cream cone corals of the first reefs, dodging school-bus-sized krakens and hungry sea scorpions."

Ancient giant cephalopods (Camerocera, Endoceras, Orthocones), sea scorpions (Eurypterid), corals (Rugosa) and the "tadpole-like" ancestors of humans (jawless Gnathostomes similar to Astraspis, early fishes sometimes called "ostracoderms"), and their "eel-like" relatives (Conodonta) all co-existed around the Ordovician period. For more, see the Cincinnati fossil taxa [here](https://strata.uga.edu/cincy/fauna/fauna.html).

> "Jawless fishes invaded the ocean, sporting points, prongs, and finally, fins."

For more on the inferred origin points for these characteristic, see this paper in *Science* ([here](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/362/6413/460/tab-figures-data)).

> "But then the glaciers came back again, and it was mass extinction number two."

The Devonian period (418-359 million years ago) was generally warm without polar ice caps but ended badly for animals. The first major glaciation (372 million years ago) is linked to the loss of coral reefs and shelled invertebrates ([here](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/9780470015902.a0001653.pub3)). The second major glaciation, 359 million years ago, covered South America and even Eastern North America with ice and is linked to extinction in fishes and other swimming animals ([here](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283748529_The_global_Hangenberg_Crisis_Devonian-Carboniferous_transition_Review_of_a_first-order_mass_extinction), [here](https://www.pnas.org/content/107/22/10131)). More minor losses happened in between, driven by invasive species ([here](https://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/22/1/article/i1052-5173-22-1-4.htm)).

> "It was the age of weird fishes and plated sea lilies. Sharks with wings. Sharks with buzz saw jaws. Sharks with fins covered in tiny teeth. Sharks with crushing tooth plates. Bony fishes that looked like modern angelfish and eels for the first time."

The "tiny teeth" refer to enlarged toothlike denticles on the sail-like fins and heads of Symmoriform "sharks" such as Stethacanthus that were extant after the end-Devonian event. For more, see [here](http://www.elasmo-research.org/education/evolution/golden_age.htm).

The sharks with "wings" are a group known as Iniopterygians, small relatives of modern ghost sharks with large pectoral fins attached to their heads. For more, see [here](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/229951020_Two_new_iniopterygians_Chondrichthyes_from_the_Mississippian_Serpukhovian_Bear_Gulch_Limestone_of_Montana_with_evidence_of_a_new_form_of_chondrichthyan_neurocranium).

In this section, "eels" refer to early species of jawed fishes that are convergent with modern eels, such as elongated ray-finned fishes and shark relatives. For more, see [here](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/05/120522200829.htm), [here](https://people.sju.edu/~egrogan/BearGulch/pages_fish_species/Paratarrasius_hibbardi.html), and [here](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/265215691_Chondrenchelys_problematica_Traquair_1888_redescribed_A_Lower_Carboniferous_eel-like_holocephalan_from_Scotland).

> "Wetlands developed, sporting ten-foot-long millipedes and giant dragonflies. These spread across the supercontinent of Pangaea and died, creating coal, leading to a 100-million-year Ice Age."

Arthropleura armata was a giant millipede that may have grown to sizes of 2.5 meters (8 feet long) during the Late Carboniferous period. For more on arthropods from the Late Devonian - Carboniferous period, see this book ([here](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://books.google.com/books?id%3DwFqrAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA238%26dq%3Dsome%2Bindividuals%2Bof%2Barthropleura%2Barmata%26hl%3Den%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Dsome%2520individuals%2520of%2520arthropleura%2520armata%26f%3Dfalse&source=gmail&ust=1582133604587000&usg=AFQjCNEY-Qc3SN3qsqNM_tBgfAqXeDpsnA)).
 
During the Carboniferous era, wetlands and swamps were widespread. At the same time, the supercontinent Pangaea was forming. For more on the Carboniferous era, see [here](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/prehistoric-world/carboniferous/).

The Late Paleozoic Ice Age lasted 100 million years and featured the lowest levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere until the last 34 million years, coincident with the burial of carbon as coal in wetlands ([here](https://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.earth.031208.100118)). However, some researchers have suggested that the Late Paleozoic Glaciation could be attributed to tectonic movement in certain parts of the former Gondwana continent, which lead to CO2 removal through weathering of exposed rocks. For more on this research, see [here](https://www.nature.com/articles/ngeo2931).

> A single, lonely tusked mammal survived and thrived ..."

As described in one paper ([here](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0169534703000934#BIB28)), Lystrosaurus was the only species of terrestrial mammal-like therapsid ([here](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/phenomena/2013/05/28/lystrosaurus-the-most-humble-badass-of-the-triassic/)) for millions of years after the end-Permian extinction event and spread out across the world as an opportunist.

> "Mammals climbed trees, flew and did a lot of other things that are seemingly sort of modern."

A few mammal species from the Mesozoic era have recently been classified as capable of gliding. For more on these species, see [here](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature24483).

> "Yeah, there's actually a lot more than these five [mass extinctions]. These are the big ones."

There are numerous extinction events that have occurred throughout the history of life on Earth, though there are considered to be five major mass extinction events. For more on the mass extinction events, see [here](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/prehistoric-world/mass-extinction/).

> "There were ecological revolutions on land and at sea, leading to the modern world. Except that an asteroid hit Mexico, and then that triggered volcanoes on the other side of the world in India, and everything almost died again."

Researchers have hypothesized that the collision in Mexico may have triggered volcanoes in what is now India. Both events are correlated with the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction. For more, see [here](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/363/6429/866) and [here](https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/06/science/study-finds-asteroid-ahead-of-dinosaur-extinction-accelerated-volcanoes.html).

> "There were palm trees and snakes in the Arctic."

50 million years ago, temperatures were so high that polar ecosystems were similar to modern tropical ones, with palm trees and reptiles (see [here](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-climate-palms/palms-grew-in-ice-free-arctic-50-million-years-ago-study-idUKTRE59O1NK20091025), [here](https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-19077439), [here](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/0031018280900644) for more). However, the distribution of the extant common European viper still includes areas north of the Arctic Circle. For more, see [here](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/vipera-berus).
